attachments.title: Computer tool spots deepfakes via tiny reflections in the eyes
attachments.text: Driven by advances in artificial intelligence, doctored video content known as deepfakes present a serious and growing danger when it comes to the spread of misinformation. As these altered clips become more and more convincing, there is a pressing need for tools that can help distinguish them fromâ€¦
attachments.fallback: New Atlas: Computer tool spots deepfakes via tiny reflections in the eyes

text: Researchers will now train better NNs to defeat these tools.

elements.text: Researchers will now train better NNs to defeat these tools.

text: the tool "just" checks whether the reflections in each eye are similar

elements.text: the tool "just" checks whether the reflections in each eye are similar

text: seems hard to enforce on a network level

elements.text: seems hard to enforce on a network level

text: maybe NN is the wrong approach. but AI researchers are smart.

elements.text: maybe NN is the wrong approach. but AI researchers are smart.

text: Adds a metalevel to the adversarial training.

elements.text: Adds a metalevel to the adversarial training.

text:
> seems hard to enforce on a network level
Why? The task of creating a full face seems a lot harder.

elements.text: seems hard to enforce on a network level
Why? The task of creating a full face seems a lot harder.

text: this is an endless story, the next net will use this 'computer tool' in their loss function to render it useless

elements.text: this is an endless story, the next net will use this 'computer tool' in their loss function to render it useless

text: the only way to win is by not publishing :smile:

elements.text: the only way to win is by not publishing

text: I'm sure there are research groups with secret AI weapons.

elements.text: I'm sure there are research groups with secret AI weapons.

text: Adversarial robustness is an arms race, just like cryptography. There's no absolute winner.

elements.text: Adversarial robustness is an arms race, just like cryptography. There's no absolute winner.

text: Arms races can be won though, just look at all extinct species :stuck_out_tongue:. And this seems to be a case where the one generating the images has a big advantage. There is only so much information in an image and it should be very possible to get to the point where there actually isn't any real information left to distinguish a fake from a real image.

elements.text: Arms races can be won though, just look at all extinct species

. And this seems to be a case where the one generating the images has a big advantage. There is only so much information in an image and it should be very possible to get to the point where there actually isn't any real information left to distinguish a fake from a real image.

text: cryptography has the advantage that theory/implementations are far ahead of possible practical attacks though, going so far as taking not-yet-known-but-thought-possible approaches into account

elements.text: cryptography has the advantage that theory/implementations are far ahead of possible practical attacks though, going so far as taking not-yet-known-but-thought-possible approaches into account
